header.title: XXXI HYMNS TO THE STAR GODDESS Who is Not

central_thesis: The central thesis is the mystical pursuit and realization of unitive gnosis with Nuit, the Thelemic Star Goddess, identified with AIN (Nothingness), or "Who is Not." Achad guides the aspirant to transcend all dualities and conventional perceptions, including the very concept of being, to merge with the infinite, all-encompassing void that Nuit represents. This is achieved through refined rapture, introspective identification with one's inner star (Khabs), and a recognition of the interconnectedness of all phenomena as expressions of the Goddess, culminating in the ultimate realization of "NOT" – a state beyond individual self and form.

structure_content.summary: A direct devotional appeal to Nuit, the 'Mother of the Sun,' for a 'Secret Kiss' and 'Holy Ecstasy,' emphasizing service through joy and recognition of her pure, sacrificial-less nature.

The mind's journey towards the 'Great Sea of Understanding' (Nuit), where the flowing consciousness seeks to reflect the 'Infinite Body' of the Goddess, identifying the self as motion and matter as part of her being.

A contemplative waiting for union within the 'Rose Garden of Life,' symbolizing Nuit as an 'Infinite Rose.' The seeker desires to penetrate her infinite petals to reach her 'Core,' which is intimately connected to the seeker's own heart, ultimately finding oneself in Her.

The aspirant stands 'tall and straight' like a Fox Glove before Nuit, embracing a 'strange conceit' of growing towards the Stars. This signifies a redirection of devotion away from mundane light sources (Sun) towards the cosmic, identifying with Nuit as 'Thy Son' and 'Thy Lover,' finding rest in the 'Womb of the Stars.'

Amidst the 'DARK NIGHT' and 'Storm,' the 'lightning flashes' of life temporarily obscure Nuit. Yet, her presence is reflected in loved ones, and the 'fires of my being' are released in honor of the unseen 'Infinite Body' of the Star Goddess, hinting at deeper perception through intensified experience.

structure_content.chapter_title: VI The Hole in The Roof
structure_content.summary: A parable contrasting limited wisdom (serpent content with a 'tiny hole') with the aspiration for boundless gnosis (beetle flying 'through the hole in the roof' into the 'Infinite Beyond'). It symbolizes forsaking conventional knowledge for direct experience of the 'Beloved Lady of the Starry Heavens.'

Contemplation of life as 'Strange CURVES' and 'Numbers' woven into a 'Musical and Harmonious Pattern.' This chapter reflects the Thelemic dictum 'Every man and every woman is a star,' emphasizing the inherent divine order and interconnectedness of individual stellar beings within Nuit's cosmic design.

A symbolic experience of dying to the mundane, where the body becomes 'blue as Thine' in a 'snow-drift' embrace of Nuit. Snowflakes are perceived as 'tiny stars,' leading to an ecstatic union with the snowdrift as Nuit's Bosom, aspiring to press one's being against her infinite body.

The 'little light of the Sun veils the Great Light of the Stars,' making Nuit seem distant. The aspirant, a 'tiny spermatozoon,' seeks to be drawn into the Sun and projected into 'Our Lady Nuit's Body' to be reborn as a new Star, thus perceiving Nuit even in daylight.

A parable of a bird moving from a small cage to a larger one, then refusing freedom. This illustrates the 'secret of Government' and how contentment in limited comfort can lead to forgetting the true desire for boundless freedom, hinting at spiritual complacency.

Expands on the bird parable, emphasizing that gaining desired comforts (like 'Dhyana' or a 'larger cage') can lead one to forget the ultimate longing for 'Real Freedom, Nirvana.' It warns against resting in intermediate states of liberation, urging the penetration of 'ultimate bars' for unity with the 'Infinitely Great as with the Infinitely Small.'

Seeking Nuit's 'Invisible Foot Prints' on Earth, finding joy in mundane beauty but desiring her joy above all. Describes Nuit's cosmic presence ('lambent flame of blue') touching the earth, seeking to comprehend her 'Being' through her subtle manifestation.

Anticipating discovering Nuit's divine 'finger tips' in nature, awaiting her grasp to be drawn into her arms, nestle at her breast, and feed on the 'Milk of the Stars.' It affirms that 'tending the Garden of the World' (magical work) leads to 'Great Reward,' and true union means knowing Nuit as she is, rather than merely perceiving her.

Describes a hidden 'well of clearest water' with a 'fiery sword' at its entrance, symbolizing a profound, esoteric source of gnosis. It alludes to challenging paths to this secret well, reinforcing the idea that 'From Thee we came; to Thee may we return, O Well of Living Stars!'

A symbolic narrative about being 'banished to the Palace of the Moon,' where 'Isis' (often representing illusion or the lunar current) veils Nuit's 'Star Splendour.' It is a prayer to lift this cold 'Veil of Isis' and dwell within Nuit's boundless 'house,' transcending limitation.

Observing a 'delicate purple mist' ascending, likened to the 'incense smoke of Aspiration' or the 'life-breath of Souls' panting for Nuit. Integrates a direct quote from *The Book of the Law* (I:26-27), describing Nuit's 'gemmèd azure' and 'naked splendour,' affirming her nature as 'all Pleasure and Purple.'

A profound desire for 'complete embrace' with Nuit, aspiring to be her 'feminine counterpart' and draw the Infinite within, or to interpenetrate every atom of her being with one's 'living flesh.' This culminates in a 'nup-tial feast' and an 'Orgasm of the Infinite Within,' birthing new 'Revolving Orbs.'

Contemplation of a rainbow formed by dew, which a spider's silken thread bridges, symbolizing the weaving of 'Destiny.' The aspirant sees themselves as an 'Arrow to the String of Destiny' in the 'bow of the Sun,' yearning to be sent into Nuit's Heart for ultimate repose.

Following a 'star-trail of Dropped Dew' left by a symbolic lady (Nuit's manifestation), leading to her 'chamber.' There, burying one's face in 'fragrant pink blossoms,' the aspirant discovers Nuit's 'secret' – 'the Dew of Love - the Elixir of Life' – without daring to look into her eyes, signifying profound reverence and intimate gnosis.

Awaiting Nuit's 'Star Body' amidst 'twilight mist,' initially chilled by 'suppressed emotion.' Recalling Nuit's words ('The Khabs is in the Khu...'), the aspirant turns inward to the 'Star of mine inmost being' (Khabs), experiencing a 'halo of rapture' and resting in Nuit's bosom, realizing the 'Mystery of Her who demandest naught in sacrifice.'

Prompted by 'Wisdom' to 'refine thy rapture,' the aspirant moves beyond being an 'unleashed hound' seeking mere reason. By turning their back on external Nuit ('face buried in the black earth') and refining rapture, they discover the hidden 'GOD' in 'DOG' (read in reverse), symbolizing an inner, inverted perception of divinity.

Observing 'roses falling' on a Full Moon night where 'children of Sin' gather, and finding a sachet of 'pot-pouri.' This scent evokes a loved one also on a 'secret tryst.' The chapter quotes Nuit's directive 'Let there be no difference made among you...' (AL I:22), questioning the significance of names and forms in the face of underlying unity.

A reimagining of Parzival's tale: the 'downy feather, steeped in blood,' from the 'Eternal Swan' (Ecstasy), transformed a 'hard pillow' into a source of sweet dreams. This led to a 'Great Vision' where stars became 'Swansdown upon the Breast of Heaven,' and every atom of the aspirant became a Star, entering the 'Great Beyond' in sleep, requesting Nuit's 'Pillow of Blood and Ecstacy.'

Affirms that 'sorrows are but shadows' that pass, while 'that which remains' (Nuit's Star Body) is constant. The moon and sun are recognized as transient illusions, with Nuit as the enduring reality, urging the aspirant never to forget her amidst fleeting phenomena.

Through parables of animals (ostrich, tortoise, hare), the chapter extols the 'wisdom of the Coiled Serpent' – a symbol of awakened Kundalini or inner power. The Serpent is wise for its hidden power, fearless head, steady progress, and swiftness, echoing Nuit's command: 'Put on the wings, arouse the coiled splendour within you: come unto me!' (AL I:51).

Explores the Qabalistic significance of the numbers 'TWENTY-SIX' (YHVH, Ahebah-Love) and 'THIRTEEN' (Echad-Unity), connecting them to the 'Inneffable Name' and the concept of 'One Substance and One Love.' It reinforces the Thelemic maxim 'Love is the law' and Achad's own numerical identification.

Meditates on the riddle: 'What is that which cometh to a point yet goeth in a circle?' This refers to Hadit (the Point) within Nuit (the Circle/Infinite). The aspirant desires to 'tear aside the veil' to see Nuit's 'Secret Glory' and resolve the 'Riddle of Life,' integrating Nuit's statement 'My colour is black to the blind...' (AL I:26) and Hadit's 'It is I that go.' (AL II:6).

Contrasts the veiled nature of Isis and Jehovah with Nuit's promises of 'unimaginable joys,' 'certainty, not faith,' and 'peace unutterable' without sacrifice. It directly quotes Hadit ('I am life and the giver of life; therefore is the knowledge of me the knowledge of death.') to highlight the profound, direct, and joyful path offered by Nuit as opposed to traditional, veiled divinities.

The 'Rays from Thy Body of Stars' (Nuit) fall upon Earth, symbolizing individual 'stars' (humans). The aspirant experiences a 'falling' into the 'void abyss of space' in ecstasy, then transforms from a 'falling star' into a 'comet wheeling in infinite Circles,' ultimately tracing Nuit's 'Infinite Sphere' and aspiring to find the 'Centre of All.'

The Fool (0=Nought/One) approaches 'Justice,' interpreting it through a Thelemic lens where 'Love is the law, love under will.' The scales of Justice, though seemingly fixed, reveal the 'Instrument of Love,' and the 'Life Sentence' is re-perceived as the 'Mystery of Imprisonment in Thy Being, O Beloved,' implying that all existence is contained within Nuit's love and will.

The ultimate realization of transcending 'Time and Space and Circumstance.' The aspirant outstrips 'a million Stars' to become one with Nuit's Body ('it is I that go'). Nuit, though 'infinitely Great,' is energized by 'the Invisible Point—the Infinitely Small' (Hadit). The final state is 'NOT' – a non-dualistic realization beyond all concepts, embracing 'Here and Now' as the infinite 'AIN.'

key_concepts.term: Nuit / The Star Goddess Who is Not
key_concepts.definition: The infinite expanse of the heavens, the omnipresent cosmic principle in Thelema. Achad identifies her with AIN (Nothingness), emphasizing her boundless and unconditioned nature beyond dualistic apprehension. She is the source of all joy and being, yet simultaneously the void into which all phenomena dissolve.

Charles Stansfeld Jones' personal, Qabalistically-informed mystical realization of Thelemic philosophy. His work is characterized by deep contemplation of numerical correspondences (e.g., 13 for unity, 26 for YHVH/Love) and the ultimate dissolution of identity into the divine 'NOT' (Ain), a profound exploration of Nuit's nature.

Derived from *The Book of the Law*, the Khabs is the innermost, secret star or divine spark within the individual, residing not in the Khu (the aura or subtle body), but rather the Khu residing within the Khabs. This concept guides the practitioner to turn inward and worship their own inherent divine essence as the path to Nuit.

The spiritual discipline of purifying and elevating ecstatic experiences from gross, animalistic passions to a higher, more subtle and spiritualized form of bliss. This refined ecstasy serves as a vehicle for deeper perception, understanding, and unitive communion with the Star Goddess.

The mystical experience of internalizing the macrocosm, where the individual consciousness fully interpenetrates and merges with the divine at an atomic level. This results in a 'new and more complete embrace' that transcends physical and conceptual boundaries, leading to an 'Orgasm of the Infinite Within.'

The foundational Thelemic maxim 'Love is the law, love under will' is explored as the driving force behind universal change, unity, and the path to Nuit. Achad views this 'Love' not as sentimental affection, but as a dynamic, unitive force that underlies all existence and impels the aspirant towards gnosis.

The fundamental mystery of existence, particularly concerning the interplay of Hadit (the atomic point) within Nuit (the infinite circle). The 'black veil' symbolizes illusion or limited perception that obscures Nuit's 'secret glory.' The aim is to penetrate this veil through gnosis to perceive the divine everywhere.

The ultimate, non-dualistic state of being, beyond both existence and non-existence, form and formlessness. It represents the dissolution of all individual identity and phenomenal reality into the primal void, Ain, which is intrinsically identified with Nuit. This is the final realization of true union and freedom.

practical_system.description: The 'practical system' outlined in these hymns is predominantly one of intense mystical devotion, contemplative gnosis, and internal alchemical transformation, rather than overt ceremonial ritual. It guides the aspirant through a series of mental, emotional, and spiritual states, utilizing poetic invocation and symbolic meditation to dissolve the ego and achieve direct unitive experience with Nuit, the Star Goddess. The practice centers on an internal re-orientation of consciousness to discover Nuit within oneself, in the macrocosm, and ultimately as the all-encompassing 'NOT.'
tools: Thelemic Scripture: Primarily *The Book of the Law* (Liber AL vel Legis), serving as the foundational text for gnosis and a source of direct pronouncements from Nuit and Hadit.
Poetic & Symbolic Meditation: Utilizing the evocative language and rich symbolic imagery present throughout the hymns as focal points for sustained contemplation and visualization.
Qabalistic Framework: Implicitly engaging with Qabalistic concepts (e.g., Ain, numerical correspondences like 13 and 26, the Tree of Life) for deeper conceptual understanding and numerical gnosis.
Self-Observation & Introspection: Continuous internal monitoring and redirection of consciousness towards the inherent divine spark within and away from illusory external phenomena.
Emotional & Ecstatic Cultivation: Deliberate generation and refinement of profound emotional states (rapture, love, joy) as a primary vehicle for spiritual ascent and direct experience of the divine.

Philosophical Paradox: Meditating upon and embracing paradoxical statements (e.g., 'Who is Not,' 'cometh to a point yet goeth in a circle') to dismantle conventional thought patterns and open pathways to non-dualistic understanding.
rituals: Devotional Invocation of Nuit: Engaging in direct poetic and emotional supplication to the Star Goddess, yearning for her 'Secret Kiss' and 'Holy Ecstasy,' as outlined in 'I Invocation.'

Contemplative Identification: Meditating on the self as an intrinsic component or reflection of Nuit, perceiving one's mind flowing into her 'Great Sea of Understanding,' and identifying one's 'Heart' with Hers ('II The Brook,' 'III The Rose Garden').

Gnostic Introspection (Khabs/Khu): Directing consciousness inward to the 'star of mine inmost being' (Khabs) to awaken a personal 'halo of rapture' and enter Nuit's bosom, following the guidance in 'XX Twilight.'

Refinement of Ecstasy: Consciously purifying and elevating personal rapture, moving beyond mere physical or emotional intensity to a higher, spiritualized form that enables true understanding and communion with the divine ('XXI The Dog Star').

Dissolution of Ego & Unitive Merge: Actively seeking the dissolution of individual consciousness into the infinite, experiencing an 'Orgasm of the Infinite Within' where every atom of one's being interpenetrates Nuit's ('XVII The Infinite Within').

Transcendence of Spatio-Temporal Limitations: Meditating on and moving beyond conventional concepts of Time, Space, and Circumstance to realize the ultimate non-dual state of 'NOT,' identifying completely with the universal Nuit ('XXXI Not').

relevant_quotes.text: All the sorrows are but shadows, they pass and are done, but there is that which remains?
I love you! I yearn to you! Pale or purple, veiled or voluptuous, I who am all pleasure and purple, and drunkenness of the innermost sense, desire you: Come unto me!
Every man and every woman is a star. Every number is infinite; there is no difference.
The Khabs is in the Khu not the Khu in the Khabs. Worship then the Khabs and behold my light shed over ye.
Above, the gemmèd azure is The naked splendour of Nuit; She bends in ecstacy to kiss The secret ardours of Hadit. The winged globe, the Starry blue, Are mine, O Ankh-af-na-khonsu!
Put on the wings, arouse the coiled splendour within you: come unto me!
There is naught that can unite the divided but love!
My colour is black to the blind, but blue and gold are seen of the seeing. Also I have a secret glory for them that love me.
I give unimaginable joys on earth, certainty, not faith, while in life upon death, peace unutterable, rest, ecstacy; nor do I demand aught in sacrifice.
Love is the law, love under will.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work holds significant relevance within Thelemic esotericism as an early and deeply personal mystical interpretation of *The Book of the Law* by one of its most prominent early adherents, Charles Stansfeld Jones (Achad). Achad's unique Qabalistic insights, particularly his emphasis on Nuit as 'Who is Not' (Ain), expanded the philosophical understanding of the Infinite and the individual's role in its realization. The hymns provide a poetic and devotional framework for direct gnosis, influencing subsequent generations of Thelemic practitioners and scholars seeking to internalize and experience the core tenets of the New Aeon. It serves as a prime example of personal, experiential mysticism within a structured occult framework.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience for this work consists of advanced Thelemic practitioners, serious Qabalists, mystics, and scholars of Western Esotericism. Its dense, symbolic language, frequent allusions to *The Book of the Law*, and reliance on specific Thelemic/Qabalistic concepts make it challenging for beginners. Readers are expected to have a foundational understanding of Thelemic philosophy, Qabalistic principles, and a disposition towards introspective, mystical contemplation.
